nodes.bodyText: Can we remove this extra space?

Extracting from the javadoc of this method :
In the case of the default provider, this method returns the same separator as {@link java.io.File#separator}.
So, you may use just File.separator here
When I introduced the filesystemSeparator()I decided to use the NIO version instead of the Java.IO FileSystems.getDefault().getSeparator();
I'm not sure that this name is more descriptive, but it meets the naming convention at least 🤔
well..the naming convention should be QuickFix right?
I meant that "fix" is ambiguous here. Only after your explanation, I understood the real purpose of the class.
Well, it's not QuickFix only there. Actually, there is no QuickFix there.
I think I need an on-demand explanation like Andrei.. so please use a better name or a comment  that clarify the intent
I would prefer to have it wrapped with Collections#unmodifiableList() to ensure immutability.
This method is unused
It was intended to be used when we cannot parse the settings. Did the idea change?
@temanbrcom is right, it is for testing purpose or for the moment we will retrieve a wider configuration section
I still see that is not used, is planned to be reused later?
yes, if needed
Ok so If I understood correctly at moment we don't need it and we can remove it - we can restore it back from the version control if needed, agree?
sure, done
These fields should be also static
Why this init for nested copybooks was removed?

Ok I got it - cause when I tested the nested copybooks I simulate that the cobol file have a reference to another copybook without psychically stor e in the file. So, is fair that you removed it from the initial activities but please remove also the method definition at line 179
There is an extra space in the constructor
Since we remove the profile concept cause is built into the path I prefer remove it as well from tests
Extra space in the constructor
